instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
Im working on an really old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No sign of water damage. Have green light but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
 starting at 6v and drops to about 1.5v. When battery connected its 12.8V and no drop but still no start and battery doesn't charge.

Dont have any working board of this old crap to compare to.

F7040 in diode mode shows 0.447V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground on L7220/60.
Same check at VREG3/5 on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
L7220 5.08 kohm
L7260 22.5 kohm

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> pin 8  dont get a value just counting up starting from 320 kohm
           pin 17 dont get a value just counting up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
Post resistance value between pins 17/18 and 27/28 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Also post voltages at pins 2, 19, 20, 1, 26, 9, 15...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: Problem around the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>. Check for corrosion and damage. Check both coils for short to GND. If all good then replace the TPS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
No sign of water damage,

<RESISTOR>R7220</RESISTOR> was bad and changed. 

Diode mode
L7260 0.431v
L7220 0.124v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: Monitor PPBUS and plug in adapter, the voltage should spike up to 12.xV and then drop down. This indicates the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is detecting an over current situation. But first need to know if the voltage comes up at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: when I not touched the board for some time it will spike up to 12.4 and then drop down but now it just go up to 1.6v and then slowly down. Just have a multimeter to test with. It measures about 0.8V long time after disconnecting charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: Connect a charged battery and AC power and see if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present from <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.

suddenly <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground so tried to insert 3.3v to the rail. After a wile the short was gone and g3h was 12.6. Green and orange light when plugged in battery and ac. Tried to power on and fan spinned for one second. After this everything was back where I started with g3h dropping and no orange light. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> only 0.063V and in diode mode 0.143V.

Another edit =) Changed <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> once again and now g3h stable at 12.6 and battery charging. quarter fan spin. But <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are 4.026V! Cant really understand what happening with this board =(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: Looks like bad soldering on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> to me, or you are measuring <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at the wrong side of L7260.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: shouldnt it be L7220? and I have 4.027V on both sides

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message: Yeah L7220 sorry. 4V is no good and means either bad soldering on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> or dead <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> or bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> or something corroded around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. If replacing anything replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> at the same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start no orange light
threads.message:
After changing chip again and still 4v I started to measure all resistors around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Find <RESISTOR>R7270</RESISTOR> was a bit off value, changed and now I have a steady 3.3V =) Happy this is a board im working on when I have no other to do. Good training on soldering chips =)

Still no start. Have quarter spin so next problem to solve
